fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A. The Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest subobject of A such that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}.

A coherent category \mathcal { C } is a Heyting category if for every morphism f \colon A \to B of \mathcal { C }, the pullback functor f ^{*} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B) \to \mathsf { Sub } (A) admits a right adjoint \forall _{f} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (A) \to \mathsf { Sub } (B). A Heyting functor between Heyting categories is a coherent functor such that for any morphism f \colon A \to B and any subobject m \colon A' \rightarrowtail A, F \forall _{f}(m) \cong \forall _{Ff}(Fm) in \mathsf { Sub } (FB). Note that this definition makes sense since coherent functors preserve monomorphisms.
Let \mathcal { C } be a Heyting category and the following square be a pullback in \mathcal { C }.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = A, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = B, sw = C, se = D, north = h, south = g, west = k, east = f, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then the following square commutes up to isomorphism.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = { \mathsf { Sub } (B)}, ne = { \mathsf { Sub } (A)}, sw = { \mathsf { Sub } (D)}, se = { \mathsf { Sub } (C)}, north = { h ^{*} }, west = { \forall _{f}}, south = { g ^{*} }, east = { \forall _{k}}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Consider the corresponding left adjoint square.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = { \mathsf { Sub } (B)}, ne = { \mathsf { Sub } (A)}, sw = { \mathsf { Sub } (D)}, se = { \mathsf { Sub } (C)}, north = { \exists _{h}}, north/style = {<-}, west = { f ^{*} }, west/style = {<-}, south = { \exists _{g}}, south/style = {<-}, east = { k ^{*} }, east/style = {<-}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: By , the two composites can be constructed as f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{g} and \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{h} k ^{*} respectively. Since images commute with pullbacks in a regular category, we have f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf { Img } f ^{*} \Sigma _{g}. Then by the pasting lemma, f ^{*} \Sigma _{g}(m) \cong \Sigma _{h} k ^{*} (m) for any subobject m \in \mathsf { Sub } (C), which assembles into a natural isomorphism f ^{*} \Sigma _{g} \cong \Sigma _{h} k ^{*}.
Thus, we can extend this natural isomorphism as follows:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: f ^{*} \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf { Img } f ^{*} \Sigma _{g} \cong \mathsf { Img } \Sigma _{h} k ^{*}
fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then both \forall _{k} h ^{*} and g ^{*} \forall _{f} are right adjoint to f ^{*} \exists _{g}, so \forall _{k} h ^{*} \cong g ^{*} \forall _{f} by the uniqueness of adjoint.
Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A. The Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest subobject of A such that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}.

Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A in a Heyting category. Then the Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} exists. Moreover, for any morphism f \colon B \to A, f ^{*} (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \cong f ^{*} (A_{1}) \Rightarrow f ^{*} (A_{2}) in \mathsf { Sub } (B).

Fix a subobject m \colon A_{1} \rightarrowtail A. Recall from that A_{1} \cap ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) may be described as \exists _{m} m ^{*}. Then take A_{1} \Rightarrow ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) to be the right adjoint of A_{1} \cap ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) given as follows:

Then for any subobject A_{2} \in \mathsf { Sub } (A) the counit of the adjunction \varepsilon _{A_{2}} \colon A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \to A_{2} says precisely that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}. And A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest such subobject by the universal property of right adjoint.
Let f \colon B \to A be a morphism. Form the following pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = { f ^{*} (A_{1})}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = B, se = A, north = g, east = m, east/style = {>->}, south = f, west = {n}, west/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley condition we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} f ^{*} (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) &:= f ^{*} \forall _{m} m ^{*} (A_{2}) \\ & \cong \forall _{n} g ^{*} m ^{*} (A_{2}) && \text {since $mg = fn$} \\ & \cong \forall _{n} n ^{*} f ^{*} (A_{2}) \\ &=: f ^{*} (A_{1}) \Rightarrow f ^{*} (A_{2}) \end {aligned}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Fix quantifiers.
Let \mathcal { C } be a sufficiently structured category. We device an (informal) internal language for \mathcal { C } as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li:
Terms:
For any pair of objects \Gamma , \Delta \in \mathcal { C }, we write f, g, h, etc for morphisms \Gamma \to \Delta in \mathcal { C }.
For any pair of composable morphisms f \colon \Delta \to \Xi and x \colon \Gamma \to \Delta, we write f(x) for their composite.
For any pair of morphisms f \colon \Gamma \to \Delta and x \colon \Xi \to \Delta, we write f { \mathopen {}[ x ] \mathclose {}} for the morphism with codomain \Xi obtained by applying the pullback functor x ^{*} to the object f in {{ \mathcal { C } }_{/{ \Delta }}}.

Formulas:
For each object \Gamma \in \mathcal { C }, we write \varphi, \psi, \chi, etc for objects in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ).
For any two parallel pair of morphisms s , t \colon \Gamma \rightrightarrows \Delta in \mathcal { C }, we write s = t for the equalizer (considered as a subobject of \Gamma) of s and t.
For any two objects \varphi , \psi \in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ), we write \varphi \wedge \psi for their intersection.
For any object \Gamma \in \mathcal { C }, we write \top for the terminal object in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ).
For any object \Gamma \in \mathcal { C }, we write \bot for the initial object in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ).
For any two objects \varphi , \psi \in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ), we write \varphi \vee \psi for their union.
For any two objects \varphi , \psi \in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ), we write \varphi \Rightarrow \psi for their Heyting implication.
For any object \varphi \in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ), we write \lnot \varphi for its pseudocomplement.
For any object \varphi \in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ) and morphism f \colon \Gamma \to \Delta, we write \exists _{f} \varphi for the subobject of \Delta obtained by applying the left adjoint \exists _{f} to \varphi.
For any object \varphi \in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ) and morphism f \colon \Gamma \to \Delta, we write \forall _{f} \varphi for for the subobject of \Delta obtained by applying the right adjoint \forall _{f} to \varphi.
For any object \psi \in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Delta ) and morphism f \colon \Gamma \to \Delta, we write \psi { \mathopen {}[ f ] \mathclose {}} for the subobject of \Gamma obtained by applying the functor f ^{*} to \psi.

Contexts: A list x_{1} \colon A_{1} , \ldots , x_{n} \colon A_{n} represents the product A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n} in \mathcal { C }. Each variable x_{i} represents the i-th projection \pi _{1} \colon A_{1} \times \cdots \times A_{n} \to A_{i}. If n = 1, then the unique variable x represents the identity morphism.

Sequents: A sequent \Gamma | \varphi \vdash \psi is intended to mean \varphi \leq \psi in the preorder \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ). We say that a sequent \Gamma | \varphi \vdash \psi is satisfied (in \mathcal { C }) if \varphi \leq \psi in \mathsf { Sub } ( \Gamma ).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a category with sufficient structure and \Gamma = x_{1} \colon B_{1} , \ldots , x_{m} \colon B_{m} be a context over a signature \Sigma. Given a \Sigma-structure M in \mathcal { C }, the interpretation of a formula-in-context \Gamma . \varphi in M is a subobject { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } \rightarrowtail M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m}) defined recursively on the structure of \varphi as follow:

fr:ul.fr:li: { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \top \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the terminal object of \mathsf { Sub } (M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m})).

{ \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi \wedge \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the intersection of { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } and { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } in \mathsf { Sub } (M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m})).

{ \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi \vee \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the union of { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } and { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } in \mathsf { Sub } (M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m})).

{ \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi \Rightarrow \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the Heyting implication { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } \Rightarrow { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } in \mathsf { Sub } (M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m})).

{ \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \lnot \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the Heyting negation of { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } in \mathsf { Sub } (M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m})).

{ \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \exists x \colon A . \mkern5mu \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the image of the following composite: { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma , x \colon A . \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } \rightarrowtail M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m},A) \xrightarrow { \pi } M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m}) where \pi is the projection of the first m factors.

{ \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \forall x \colon A . \mkern5mu \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is \forall _{ \pi }( { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma , x \colon A . \varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } ), where \forall _{ \pi } is the right adjoint associated with a Heyting category and \pi \colon M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m},A) \to M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m}) is the projection of the first m factors.

{ \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \bigvee _{i \in I} \varphi _{i} \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the arbitrary union of each { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi _{i} \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } in \mathsf { Sub } (M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m})).

{ \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \bigwedge _{i \in I} \varphi _{i} \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } is the arbitrary intersection of each { \mathopen {} \llbracket \Gamma . \varphi _{i} \rrbracket \mathclose {}} _{ M } in \mathsf { Sub } (M(B_{1}, \ldots ,B_{m})).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A_{1} and A_{2} be two subobjects of A in a Heyting category. Then the Heyting implication A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} exists. Moreover, for any morphism f \colon B \to A, f ^{*} (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \cong f ^{*} (A_{1}) \Rightarrow f ^{*} (A_{2}) in \mathsf { Sub } (B).

Fix a subobject m \colon A_{1} \rightarrowtail A. Recall from that A_{1} \cap ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) may be described as \exists _{m} m ^{*}. Then take A_{1} \Rightarrow ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) to be the right adjoint of A_{1} \cap ( \mathord { \hspace {1pt} \text {--} \hspace {1pt}} ) given as follows:

Then for any subobject A_{2} \in \mathsf { Sub } (A) the counit of the adjunction \varepsilon _{A_{2}} \colon A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) \to A_{2} says precisely that A_{1} \cap (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) is contained in A_{2}. And A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2} is the largest such subobject by the universal property of right adjoint.
Let f \colon B \to A be a morphism. Form the following pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = { f ^{*} (A_{1})}, nw/style = {pullback}, ne = {A_{1}}, sw = B, se = A, north = g, east = m, east/style = {>->}, south = f, west = {n}, west/style = {>->}, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Then by Beck-Chevalley condition we have
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: \begin {aligned} f ^{*} (A_{1} \Rightarrow A_{2}) &:= f ^{*} \forall _{m} m ^{*} (A_{2}) \\ & \cong \forall _{n} g ^{*} m ^{*} (A_{2}) && \text {since $mg = fn$} \\ & \cong \forall _{n} n ^{*} f ^{*} (A_{2}) \\ &=: f ^{*} (A_{1}) \Rightarrow f ^{*} (A_{2}) \end {aligned}
